Grouped_Utterances: Hi, Ellie! I’ve been doing well. I’ve been trying to practice communicating more with my family. It’s been good. I had another family dinner, and I shared my feelings about how proud I am of them. I realize now that I missed a lot of opportunities to connect because I was too focused on my own fears. I’d like to work on my relationship with my youngest daughter. We’ve had some misunderstandings lately. I think it’s a mix of different perspectives. We have different views on parenting and life choices.

They were really receptive. My daughters seemed touched, and my granddaughters smiled a lot. I felt lighter, like a weight was lifted. It felt good to express myself. I feel closer to them. I think they appreciate me more, and I appreciate them more too. I feel more confident. I think it’ll help clear the air.

You might begin by saying, “I’ve noticed we’ve had some differences lately, and I’d really like to understand your perspective better. Can you share how you feel?”  One technique is to take a deep breath before responding, especially if you feel triggered. You could also try to reframe your thoughts, reminding yourself that it’s okay to disagree and that understanding is the goal.

I think I need to remind myself to listen and be open, just like I’ve been trying to do with my family. I could ask her how she feels about things and really try to understand her viewpoint. I think I’d like to work on being more patient during conversations, especially when I feel defensive. I think it’ll be helpful. I want to be more mindful. I’d like to reflect on how my conversations with my daughter go and what I learn from them.
